item.title: Correlation Doesn't Even Imply ... Correlation, Necessarily
item.description: There’s a problem with the various versions of the oft-heard-in-intro-stats-courses phrase “correlation does not imply causation.” It gives early statistics students the wrong impressions. The idea seems simple: Just becuase there is statistical correlation in the data present does not mean that that there is a real world causal relationship (a complicated term, it turns out) between x and y. You know, x could have a high correlation with y but actually, w is simply a mutual cause of x and y.
